content: Across southeast Asia **[Nasi goreng](/wiki/Nasi_goreng)** (lit: Fried rice) has developed into a wide array of [variations](/wiki/Nasi_goreng#Variations) throughout Southeast Asia, reflecting local ingredients, culinary traditions and cultural influences. Originating from [Chinese fried rice](/wiki/Chinese_fried_rice) techniques, it was adapted over time to suit the tastes and available ingredients of [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia), [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), [Brunei](/wiki/Brunei) and [southern Thailand](/wiki/Southern_Thailand). Variants differ in their primary components, including chicken, seafood, vegetables, or region-specific ingredients such as shredded cabbage*,* *petai* ([stinky bean](/wiki/Stinky_bean)) and *kluwek* (black keluak fruit). Some forms of nasi goreng are named after their geographic or cultural origins, including *nasi goreng Aceh*, *nasi goreng Bali*, *nasi goreng Jawa* and *nasi goreng Padang.* Others are identified by their cooking methods or presentation, such as *nasi goreng amplop* (wrapped in an [omelette](/wiki/Omelette)), *nasi goreng bakar* (grilled in [banana leaf](/wiki/Banana_leaf)) and *nasi goreng pelangi* (rainbow fried rice with colourful vegetables). These adaptations underscore the dish's flexibility and its widespread presence in both household meals and street-food culture. In addition to traditional preparations, nasi goreng has absorbed external culinary influences. Variants such as *nasi goreng Jepang* and *nasi goreng Hongkong* reflect Japanese and Chinese styles, while adaptations like *nasi goreng keju* incorporate Western ingredients. The extensive diversity of nasi goreng variants highlights its enduring popularity and positions the dish as a versatile canvas for regional flavours. The following list categorises these variants, providing examples by main ingredient, region, and style of preparation. ## Indonesia This article is part of the series on[Indonesian cuisine](/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine) *Masakan Indonesia*National dishes - [Gado-gado](/wiki/Gado-gado) - [Nasi goreng](/wiki/Nasi_goreng) - [Rendang](/wiki/Rendang) - [Satay](/wiki/Satay) - [Soto](/wiki/Soto_(food)) - [Tumpeng](/wiki/Tumpeng) Regional and cultural cuisines - [Acehnese](/wiki/Acehnese_cuisine) - [Arab](/wiki/Arab_Indonesian_cuisine) - [Balinese](/wiki/Balinese_cuisine) - [Banjarese](/wiki/Banjarese_cuisine) - [Batak](/wiki/Batak_cuisine) - [Betawi](/wiki/Betawi_cuisine) - [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_Indonesian_cuisine) - [Gorontalese](/wiki/Gorontalo_cuisine) - [Indian](/wiki/Indian_Indonesian_cuisine) - [Indo](/wiki/Indo_cuisine) - [Javanese](/wiki/Javanese_cuisine) - [Madurese](/wiki/Madurese_cuisine) - [Makassarese](/wiki/Makassarese_cuisine) - [Malay](/wiki/Malay_cuisine) - [Minahasan](/wiki/Minahasan_cuisine) - [Minangkabau](/wiki/Padang_cuisine) - [Palembangese](/wiki/Palembangese_cuisine) - [Peranakan](/wiki/Peranakan_cuisine) - [Sundanese](/wiki/Sundanese_cuisine) Ingredients - *[Bumbu](/wiki/Bumbu_(seasoning))* - [Condiments](/wiki/List_of_Indonesian_condiments) - [Peanut sauce](/wiki/Peanut_sauce) - *[Sambal](/wiki/Sambal)* - *[Santan](/wiki/Coconut_milk)* Types of food**Foods** - [Dishes](/wiki/List_of_Indonesian_dishes) - [Noodles](/wiki/Indonesian_noodles) - [Soups](/wiki/List_of_Indonesian_soups) - [Desserts](/wiki/List_of_Indonesian_desserts) - [Snacks](/wiki/List_of_Indonesian_snacks) - *[Kue](/wiki/Kue)* - *[Krupuk](/wiki/Krupuk)* - *[Kripik](/wiki/Kripik)* **Drinks** - [Beverages](/wiki/List_of_Indonesian_drinks) - [Alcohol](/wiki/Alcohol_in_Indonesia) - [Coffee](/wiki/Coffee_production_in_Indonesia) Preparation and cooking**Main** - [Frying](/wiki/Frying) - [Stir frying](/wiki/Stir_frying) - [Grilling](/wiki/Grilling) - [Roasting](/wiki/Roasting) - [Dry roasting](/wiki/Dry_roasting) - [Sautéing](/wiki/Saut%C3%A9ing) - [Boiling](/wiki/Boiling) - [Steaming](/wiki/Steaming) **Other** - [Pepes](/wiki/Pepes) - [Pindang](/wiki/Pindang) - [Rendang](/wiki/Rendang) - [Semur](/wiki/Semur_(Indonesian_stew)) Styles - [Nasi campur](/wiki/Nasi_campur) - [Nasi padang](/wiki/Nasi_padang) - [Rijsttafel](/wiki/Rijsttafel) - [Tumpeng](/wiki/Tumpeng) - [Street food](/wiki/Street_food_of_Indonesia) Holidays and festivals - *[Kenduri](/wiki/Kenduri)* - [*Lebaran* (Eid al-Fitr)](/wiki/Lebaran#Lebaran_feast) - *[Naloni Mitoni](/wiki/Naloni_Mitoni)* - [*Natal* (Christmas)](/wiki/List_of_Christmas_dishes#Indonesia) - *[Serak Gulo](/wiki/Serak_Gulo)* - *[Slametan](/wiki/Slametan)* Related cuisines - [Bruneian](/wiki/Bruneian_cuisine) - [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_cuisine) - [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_cuisine) - [East Timorese](/wiki/Cuisine_of_East_Timor) - [Egyptian](/wiki/Egyptian_cuisine) - [Filipino](/wiki/Filipino_cuisine) - [Indian](/wiki/Indian_cuisine) - [Malaysian](/wiki/Malaysian_cuisine) - [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_cuisine) - [Singaporean](/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine) - [Sri Lankan](/wiki/Sri_Lankan_cuisine) - [South African](/wiki/South_African_cuisine) - [Surinamese](/wiki/Surinamese_cuisine) - [Thai](/wiki/Thai_cuisine) - [Yemeni](/wiki/Yemeni_cuisine) See also - [History](/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine#History) - [Etiquette](/wiki/Etiquette_in_Indonesia#Table_manner) - Cookbook: Cuisine of Indonesia Indonesia portal Food portal - v - t - e Many variants are named after their main ingredients, others after their city or region of origin. Specific examples of *nasi goreng* include: 1. *Nasi goreng Aceh* (Acehnese fried rice), rich in spices akin to *[mie aceh](/wiki/Mie_aceh)* 2. *Nasi goreng amplop* (egg-enveloped fried rice), known as *nasi goreng pattaya* in Malaysia. 3. *Nasi goreng andaliman* (with *[andaliman](/wiki/Andaliman)* or locally known as "Batak pepper"), specialty of North Sumatra 4. *Nasi goreng anglo* chicken fried rice cooked on *anglo* traditional terracotta brazier which contributed to its woody charcoal aroma. 5. *Nasi goreng ati ampela* (with chicken [liver](/wiki/Liver_(food)) and [gizzard](/wiki/Gizzard)) 6. *Nasi goreng ayam* (with chicken) 7. *Nasi goreng babat gongso* (with [tripe](/wiki/Tripe)), a tripe fried rice from [Semarang](/wiki/Semarang) 8. *Nasi goreng babi* (with pork, usually served with Chinese [pork belly](/wiki/Pork_belly) and *[charsiu](/wiki/Charsiu)*) 9. *Nasi goreng bakar*, (grilled fried rice), a hybrid between nasi goreng and *[nasi bakar](/wiki/Nasi_bakar)*, fried rice is wrapped inside banana leaf pocket, and grilled upon charcoal fire. 10. *Nasi goreng bakso* (with [bakso](/wiki/Bakso) meatball) 11. *Nasi goreng Bali* ([Balinese](/wiki/Balinese_cuisine) fried rice), rich in spices including chopped lemongrass, turmeric, shallot, garlic and galangal, and uses no soy sauce. 12. *Nasi goreng bayam* (spinach fried rice) 13. *Nasi goreng bebek* (with fried [duck](/wiki/Duck_as_food)) 14. *Nasi goreng biru* (blue fried rice) or *nasi goreng bunga telang*, blue-coloured fried rice acquired from *bunga telang* or the flower of *[Clitoria ternatea](/wiki/Clitoria_ternatea)*. 15. *Nasi goreng buah merah*, Papuan fried rice with extract of *buah merah* (*[Pandanus conoideus](/wiki/Pandanus_conoideus)*) 16. *Nasi goreng buah naga* (red [pitaya](/wiki/Pitaya) fried rice) 17. *Nasi goreng cakalang* (with [skipjack tuna](/wiki/Skipjack_tuna)), speciality of [Manado](/wiki/Manado_cuisine) 18. *Nasi goreng cumi* (with [squid](/wiki/Squid_as_food)) 19. *Nasi goreng daging asap* (with [smoked beef](/wiki/Smoked_beef)) 20. *Nasi goreng daun jeruk* (with shredded [lime](/wiki/Kaffir_lime) leaves) which contributed to its citrus aroma and greenish hue. 21. *Nasi goreng domba* (with mutton) 22. *Nasi goreng dendeng lemak* (with fatty [dendeng](/wiki/Dendeng) thin beef jerky) also known as *nasi goreng tiarbah* 23. *Nasi goreng ebi* (with salted [dried shrimp](/wiki/Dried_shrimp)) 24. *Nasi goreng gila* (crazy fried rice), fried rice topped with more savoury additional ingredients including chicken, meat, shrimp, sliced bakso, sausages, egg, etc. 25. *Nasi goreng hijau* (green fried rice), green-coloured fried rice acquired from ground green chilli pepper and chopped [lemon basil](/wiki/Lemon_basil). 26. *Nasi goreng hitam* (black fried rice), or *nasi goreng cumi hitam*, coloured and flavoured with squid ink 27. *Nasi goreng ikan asin* (with [salted fish](/wiki/Salted_fish)) 28. *Nasi goreng jamur* (with mushroom) 29. *Nasi goreng jancuk*, extra hot and spicy fried rice from [Surabaya](/wiki/Surabaya) 30. *[Nasi goreng Jawa](/wiki/Nasi_goreng_jawa)* (Javanese fried rice) 31. *Nasi goreng jengkol* (with [jengkol](/wiki/Jengkol) stinky pea) 32. *Nasi goreng kacang polong* (with [green peas](/wiki/Green_pea)) 33. *Nasi goreng kambing* (with goat meat), particularly renowned in the Kebon Sirih area in Central Jakarta. 34. *Nasi goreng kebuli*, a hybrid recipe of fried rice with spices akin to *[nasi kebuli](/wiki/Nasi_kebuli)* 35. *Nasi goreng kecombrang* (with *kecombrang* or [torch ginger](/wiki/Torch_ginger)) 36. *Nasi goreng keju* (with cheese, either [mozzarella](/wiki/Mozzarella) or [cheddar](/wiki/Cheddar_cheese)) 37. *Nasi goreng kencur* or *nasi goreng cikur* in [sundanese](/wiki/Sundanese_language), fried rice made of rice cooked with spices made of chili, garlic, onion and *kencur* ([aromatic ginger](/wiki/Kaempferia_galanga)) 38. *Nasi goreng kerang* (with [cockle](/wiki/Cockle_(bivalve))) 39. *Nasi goreng kluwek* (seasoned with *[kluwek](/wiki/Pangium_edule)* or *keluak* fruit), which create blackish colour 40. *Nasi goreng kornet* (with [corned beef](/wiki/Corned_beef) and margarine) 41. *Nasi goreng krengsengan* (with meat and fresh cabbage), spicy fried rice with chopped noodles and meat, similar to nasi goreng Magelangan 42. *Nasi goreng kuah*, fried rice with soupy chicken broth from [Kediri](/wiki/Kediri_(city)), East Java. 43. *Nasi goreng kuah susu*, fried rice added with milk soup and grated cheese. 44. *Nasi goreng kuah tongseng*, fried rice added with [tongseng](/wiki/Tongseng) soup. 45. *Nasi goreng lada hitam* ([black pepper](/wiki/Black_pepper) fried rice) 46. *Nasi goreng Madura* ([Madura](/wiki/Madura) fried rice) applies fine garlic spices. Madura fried rice is common in [Pontianak](/wiki/Pontianak), it uses bean sprouts and no sweet soy sauce. 47. *Nasi goreng Magelangan* ([Magelang](/wiki/Magelang) fried rice) or also called as *nasi goreng mawut* or *nasi goreng ruwet* (scrambled or mixed up fried rice), a combo of fried rice and noodle with vegetables and spices 48. *Nasi goreng merah* or *nasi goreng Makassar* (red fried rice) 49. *Nasi goreng nanas* ([pineapple](/wiki/Pineapple) fried rice), also known as *nasi goreng Hawaii* or *nasi goreng Thailand* 50. *Nasi goreng oncom kencur* (with *[oncom](/wiki/Oncom)* and *[kencur](/wiki/Kencur)*), a [Sundanese](/wiki/Sundanese_cuisine) fried rice variant 51. *Nasi goreng Padang* ([Padang](/wiki/Padang_food) fried rice), also rich in spices similar to Aceh fried rice 52. *Nasi goreng pedas*, hot and spicy fried rice with chili peppers 53. *Nasi goreng pelangi* (rainbow fried rice), without soy sauce with colourful vegetables 54. *Nasi goreng pete/petai* (with [green stinky bean](/wiki/Parkia_speciosa)) 55. *Nasi goreng petis* (with *[petis udang](/wiki/Petis)*), a type of thick black shrimp paste with molasses like consistency, specialty of East Java 56. *Nasi goreng petir* (lit: "thunderbolt fried rice"), an extra hot and spicy fried rice 57. *Nasi goreng platar* or "fried rice [platter](/wiki/Platter_(dishware))", a hotel's restaurant style of serving *nasi goreng*. 58. *Nasi goreng pliket* or *sego pliket* (Javanese for "sticky fried rice") goat fried rice with sticky texture because of the addition of goat bone marrow. 59. *Nasi goreng rawit*, extra hot and spicy fried rice with *cabe rawit* or [bird's eye chili](/wiki/Bird%27s_eye_chili) 60. *Nasi goreng rendang* ([rendang](/wiki/Rendang) fried rice), rich and spicy fried rice usually made from leftover rendang spices 61. *Nasi goreng rempah*, spicy fried rice with ample of *[bumbu](/wiki/Bumbu_(seasoning))* spice mixture 62. *Nasi goreng resek*, fried rice with shredded chicken, beansprouts, and cabbages, specialty of [Malang](/wiki/Malang) city in East Java. 63. *Nasi goreng roa* (with [halfbeak](/wiki/Halfbeak) fish), also speciality of [Manado](/wiki/Manado_cuisine) 64. *Nasi goreng sambal ijo/hijau* (green *sambal* fried rice), often simply called *nasi goreng hijau* (green fried rice) 65. *Nasi goreng sambal terasi* (*[Sambal](/wiki/Sambal)* shrimp paste fried rice), or simply *nasi goreng terasi* (*[terasi](/wiki/Terasi)* shrimp paste fried rice) 66. *Nasi goreng santri* (vegetarian fried rice) 67. *Nasi goreng sapi* (with beef) 68. *Nasi goreng sarden* (with [sardines](/wiki/Canned_sardines)) 69. *Nasi goreng saus tiram* ([oyster sauce](/wiki/Oyster_sauce) fried rice) 70. *Nasi goreng saus teriyaki* ([teriyaki sauce](/wiki/Teriyaki_sauce) fried rice) usually beef or chicken fried rice in teriyaki sauce, a Japanese influence in Indonesia 71. *Nasi goreng seafood* (with seafood, such as squid, fish, fish or shrimp meatball and shrimp) 72. *Nasi goreng serundeng* (with *[serundeng](/wiki/Serundeng)* or sauteed grated coconut flakes) 73. *Nasi goreng setan* (devil's fried rice), extra hot and spicy fried rice with various types of chili peppers, including sambal paste, sliced fresh bird's-eye chili and [chili powder](/wiki/Chili_powder). 74. *Nasi goreng siram* (fried rice poured with chicken and vegetables soup/sauce) 75. *Nasi goreng sosis* (with beef or chicken [sausages](/wiki/Sausage)) 76. *Nasi goreng spesial* (special fried rice) with complete ingredients, including chicken, egg mixed in rice, sausages, vegetables, and topped with sunny side up [fried egg](/wiki/Fried_egg) 77. *Nasi goreng Sunda* ([Sundanese](/wiki/Sundanese_cuisine) fried rice), spicy fried rice with ample of *kunyit* (turmeric) which add golden yellow colour 78. *Nasi goreng Surabaya* ([Surabaya](/wiki/Surabaya) fried rice) contains chicken, shrimp, *bakso* (meatball), egg and vegetables 79. *Nasi goreng tahu* (with [tofu](/wiki/Tofu)) 80. *Nasi goreng tek-tek*, fried rice version of mi tek-tek noodle. Usually served by *mi tek-tek* peddler that announce their presence in the neighborhood by hitting the metal wok creating "tek-tek" sounds. 81. *Nasi goreng telur* (with egg) 82. *Nasi goreng telur asin* (with [salted duck egg](/wiki/Salted_duck_egg)) 83. *Nasi goreng tembakau* (with [tobacco](/wiki/Tobacco) seeds), specialty of [Temanggung](/wiki/Temanggung_Regency), a tobacco plantation area 84. *Nasi goreng terasi* (with terasi [shrimp paste](/wiki/Shrimp_paste)) 85. *Nasi goreng teri Medan* (with Medan's anchovy) 86. *Nasi goreng tomat* (tomato fried rice) 87. *Nasi goreng tongkol asap* (with smoked [mackerel tuna](/wiki/Euthynnus_affinis)) 88. *Nasi goreng tuna* (with [tuna](/wiki/Tuna_as_food)) 89. *Nasi goreng udang* (with shrimp) 90. *Nasi goreng usus* (with [intestine](/wiki/Intestine)) Indonesians also called foreign versions of fried rice simply as *nasi goreng*, thus *nasi goreng Hongkong* and *nasi goreng Tionghoa/China* refer to Chinese fried rice, while *nasi goreng Jepang* refer to *yakimeshi* or *chahan*. ## Brunei, Malaysia and Singapore This article **needs additional citations for verification**. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. *Find sources:* "List of variations of nasi goreng" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(September 2025)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)*This article is part of the series on[Malaysian cuisine](/wiki/Malaysian_cuisine) *Masakan Malaysia*Regional and cultural cuisines - [Chinese](/wiki/Malaysian_Chinese_cuisine) - [Eurasian](/wiki/Eurasian_cuisine_of_Singapore_and_Malaysia) - [Indian](/wiki/Malaysian_Indian_cuisine) - [Javanese](/wiki/Javanese_cuisine) - [Malay](/wiki/Malay_cuisine) - [Peranakan](/wiki/Peranakan_cuisine) - [Sabah](/wiki/Sabahan_cuisine) - [Sarawak](/wiki/Sarawakian_cuisine) Ingredients - *[Belacan](/wiki/Shrimp_paste)* - *[Budu](/wiki/Budu_(sauce))* - *[Gula Melaka](/wiki/Palm_sugar)* - *[Kerisik](/wiki/Kerisik)* - *[Kicap Manis](/wiki/Sweet_soy_sauce)* - *[Pandan](/wiki/Pandanus_amaryllifolius)* - *[Sambal](/wiki/Sambal)* - *[Santan](/wiki/Coconut_milk)* - *[Tapai](/wiki/Tapai)* - *[Tempoyak](/wiki/Tempoyak)* Types of food**Foods** - [Dishes](/wiki/List_of_Malaysian_dishes) - [Soups](/wiki/Sup_kambing) - *[Kuih](/wiki/Kuih)* - *[Keropok](/wiki/Krupuk)* - *[Kerepek](/wiki/Kripik)* **Drinks** - - [Alcohol](/wiki/Alcohol_in_Malaysia) Holidays and festivals - [Chinese New Year](/wiki/Chinese_New_Year) - [Hari Raya Puasa](/wiki/Eid_al-Fitr) - [Hari Raya Qurban](/wiki/Eid_al-Adha) - [Deepavali](/wiki/Deepavali) - [Christmas](/wiki/Christmas) - [Tadau Kaamatan](/wiki/Kaamatan) - [Gawai](/wiki/Gawai_Dayak) Related cuisines - [Bruneian](/wiki/Bruneian_cuisine) - [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_cuisine) - [Filipino](/wiki/Filipino_cuisine) - [Indian](/wiki/Indian_cuisine) - [Indonesian](/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine) - [Singaporean](/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine) - [Thai](/wiki/Thai_cuisine) See also - [History](/wiki/Malaysian_cuisine#History) - Cookbook: Cuisine of Malaysia - [Ipoh cuisine](/wiki/Ipoh_cuisine) Malaysia portal Food portal - v - t - e Popular variants of nasi goreng in Brunei, Malaysia and Singapore include: 1. *Nasi goreng ayam* (fried rice usually served with [crispy fried chicken](/wiki/Fried_chicken) with sweet chilli sauce) 2. *Nasi goreng belacan* (fried with leftover [sambal belacan](/wiki/Sambal) and fish or other meats) 3. *Nasi goreng blackpepper* (fried rice with chicken or beef in [blackpepper sauce](/wiki/Black_pepper)) 4. *Nasi goreng cendawan* (fried rice cooked with [mushrooms](/wiki/Mushroom)) 5. *Nasi goreng cili api/masak pedas* (spicy fried rice served with chicken/beef) 6. *Nasi goreng chicken chop* (Malaysian Eurasian food) 7. *Nasi goreng dabai* (a Sarawak speciality which the rice is fried with a seasonal native fruit called 'buah dabai' ([Borneo olive](/wiki/Borneo_olive))). 8. *Nasi goreng daging/kambing* (fried rice with beef or mutton) 9. *Nasi goreng ikan masin* (fried with [salted fish](/wiki/Salted_fish)) 10. *Nasi goreng kampung* (fried with [anchovies](/wiki/Anchovy)/leftover fried fish, *[kangkong](/wiki/Ipomoea_aquatica)*) 11. *Nasi goreng kerabu* (fried rice with local salads) 12. *Nasi goreng kunyit* (fried rice served with turmeric and meat with onions, long beans and carrots) 13. *Nasi goreng kari* (fried rice cooked with [curry](/wiki/Curry)) 14. *Nasi goreng ladna* (fried rice cooked with seafood and vegetables in white gravy) 15. *Nasi goreng masak merah* (fried rice with chicken or beef in chilli gravy) 16. *Nasi goreng mamak* ([Indian Muslim](/wiki/Mamak_stall) style nasi goreng) 17. *Nasi goreng nenas* (fried rice cooked with [pineapples](/wiki/Pineapple)) 18. *Nasi goreng paprik* (fried rice served with paprik dish, usually chicken) 19. *[Nasi goreng pattaya](/wiki/Nasi_goreng_pattaya)* (fried rice in an [omelette](/wiki/Omelette) envelope which is topped with chili sauce or tomato sauce, sometimes includes chicken) 20. *Nasi goreng petai* (fried rice cooked with [parkia speciosa](/wiki/Parkia_speciosa)) 21. *Nasi goreng seafood* (fried with [prawn](/wiki/Prawn), [calamari](/wiki/Squid_as_food) slices and [crab sticks](/wiki/Crab_stick)) 22. *Nasi goreng sotong* (fried rice cooked with calamary) 23. *Nasi goreng telur* (fried rice served with [fried eggs](/wiki/Fried_egg)) 24. *Nasi goreng tomyam* (fried rice cooked in [tomyum](/wiki/Tom_yum) paste) 25. *Nasi goreng udang* (fried rice cooked with prawn) 26. *Nasi goreng USA* (fried rice with three core ingredients namely prawn (**u**dang), squid (**s**otong) and chicken (**a**yam)) 27. *[Nasi goreng Amerika](/wiki/American_fried_rice#Muslim_version_(Southern_Thailand_and_Malaysia))* (with fried egg and [stir fried](/wiki/Stir_frying) beef in chili sauce) 28. *Nasi goreng pulau Brunei* (floating fried rice, a Brunei specialty) 29. *Nasi goreng belutak* (fried rice with [belutak](/wiki/Belutak), the traditional Bruneian beef sausage) 30. *Nasi goreng corned beef* (fried with [corned beef](/wiki/Corned_beef), popular in Brunei and Sarawak) ## Gallery - Nasi goreng variants - Food portal - Indonesia portal - Malaysia portal - Singapore portal - Sri Lanka portal - [Fried rice](/wiki/Fried_rice) - [List of fried rice dishes](/wiki/List_of_fried_rice_dishes) - [Sinangág](/wiki/Sinang%C3%A1g) - [Cuisine of Brunei](/wiki/Bruneian_cuisine) - [Cuisine of Indonesia](/wiki/Cuisine_of_Indonesia) - [Cuisine of Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysian_cuisine) - [Cuisine of Singapore](/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine) - [Cuisine of the Netherlands](/wiki/Dutch_cuisine) - [Biryani](/wiki/Biryani)
title: List of variations of nasi goreng
